clinical_study.official_title: Mechanisms of Immunotoxicology in Cancer Patients

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to better understand how the treatment of cancer with immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) leads to the development of autoimmunity. Specifically, we wish to understand the genetics and immune system features that cause a subset of cancer patients treated with checkpoint inhibitor therapy to develop an immune-related adverse event (irAE).

primary_outcome.measure: The phenotype and function of peripheral blood cells (i.e., CD4+ T cells, CD8+ T cells, B cells, myeloid cells) characteristic to patients receiving checkpoint inhibitor therapy.
primary_outcome.description: The phenotypic analysis will include multiple surface markers that define populations of cells, including activated, memory, and regulatory populations. Cells will also be activated to determine which cytokines are produced.

primary_outcome.measure: The prevalence of immune-related adverse events (irAEs) that complicate checkpoint inhibitor therapy.

secondary_outcome.measure: The number of future research studies and/or collaborations resulting directly from the databank of tissues and other relevant clinical information that will be established.

arm_group.description: Adult patients with a diagnosis of cancer receiving checkpoint inhibitor therapy at the University of Pennsylvania's Abramson Cancer Center (ACC).

biospec_descr.textblock:
50 mls of peripheral blood will be drawn at the time that patients are prescribed an immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) which will be banked for serum and PBMCs. No more than 50 mls of blood will be drawn at three established subsequent points: at the time of the second drug infusion (8-12 weeks after the first infusion), at 6 months and at 12 months. Additionally, no more than 50 mls of blood will be drawn at any time that a participant develops an autoimmune complication.
An assessment tool that queries symptoms suggestive of a number of common immunotherapy-related adverse events (PRO-CTCAE) will be administered to consented patients at each visit in concert with the standard-of-care patient reported outcomes tool currently in use in Cancer Center clinics.

study_pop.textblock: Adults who are able to consent to the study and are identified by their physician or a clinical coordinator to receive an immune checkpoint inhibitor for the treatment of cancer.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- A diagnosis of cancer and prescription for a checkpoint inhibitor
Exclusion Criteria:
- Any subjects not willing or able to give consent
- Children under the age of 18
- A history of transplant
